content: What's the plan for reallyConvexHull/ReallyConvex? (https://github.com/leanprover-community/sphere-eversion/blob/master/SphereEversion/ToMathlib/Analysis/Convex/Basic.lean) Should it replace the mathlib definition? Is someone working on it?

Good question; I've been idly wondering since I first saw that file. I eventual strategy always was "ask Yael about the convexity definition", but I think proceeding under the assumption that mathlib's convexity refactor will not happen yet is safe.
I'm not aware of anybody working on this. Feel free to do so!
Well, I can't answer the question "why is this better than what mathlib has", so I'm not sure I'm the right person to propose it :)
Perhaps if someone wanted to talk me through it first :innocent:
Note that our new docs#ConvexSpace is inherently n-ary, so generalizing our docs#Convex to this generality will "naturally" encompass the ReallyConvex version.
In other words, the correct way to fix this is to generalise mathlib?

Definitely, I think the current definition of docs#Convex is just wrong in this context. IIRC, the issue is that, for convexity over a ring with zero divisors (e.g a ring of functions), being stable under binary convex combinations does not imply being stable by n-ary convex combinations.
Yes, Anatole precisely described the point of this ReallyConvex stuff.

Ruben Van de Velde said:

Looking forward to your pr :)

I don't have time for this at all, unfortunately... If you want I can open an issue laying down what needs to be done. I think the first step is making docs#Convex irreducible: right now we rely on the exact definition a lot, which we have to avoid before even attempting a refactor.

Note that I'm not claiming that it should be irreducible forever: once more and more of the library uses docs#ConvexSpace.convexCombination (should we shorten it?) it might be useful to allow unfolding the definition, but for the sake of the refactor I think irreducibility will help a lot.
